title: What’s the difference between a dissertation and a thesis? - Quora

response.answer_text: What’s the difference between a dissertation and a thesis? (A2A - thanks for asking) The two terms are sometimes used interchangeably, but there are some big differences between them. A dissertation is usually the capstone project for a doctorate while a thesis is more commonly done at the master’s level. Depending on the country and subject area, the term “thesis” could be applied to doctoral level work, but “dissertation” is the more commonly used term for this. A dissertation is expected to be a piece of original research that adds to the body of knowledge in a given field. A thesis (master’s level) can be, but is not necessarily expected to be original research as much as it is supposed to be a demonstration of the student’s mastery of the literature and methods appropriate to the field. A thesis (master’s level) is commonly prepared over the course of one or two semesters. A dissertation, by contrast, can take several years of preparation. In keeping with this, a thesis is usually shorter than a dissertation. I’ll note in passing that David Rector’s doctoral thesis (MIT 1969) was nine pages: intro, three pages of math, and a bibliography, so length is not necessarily a defining characteristic a long as the work is original. I don’t know that this is the shortest ever, but it has to be in that ballpark. Anecdotally, I’m told that Rector’s supervisor liked short papers, so this may have contributed.

Usually dissertation and thesis in most universities seen as a same thing.. But the major difference is that thesis submitted at the end of master’s program and dissertation marked in a Ph.D (doctorate level program)
